articles.headline: Fannie Mae Chief Details Plan to Ease Mortgage Rules
articles.snippet: The chief executive of Fannie Mae said that Fannie would accept more low down payment mortgages but would require private mortgage insurance as well.
articles.abstract: The chief executive of Fannie Mae said that Fannie would accept more low down payment mortgages but would require private mortgage insurance as well.
articles.lead_paragraph: Seeking to bring more people into the housing market, the government said last month that it planned to expand the availability of mortgages with low down payments.

articles.headline: Chance for Tax Overhaul Is Seen in Shift of Power
articles.snippet: Tax restructuring, international trade and budget policy may offer common ground for Democrats and Republicans in President Obama’s final two years in office.
articles.abstract: Tax restructuring, international trade and budget policy may offer common ground for Democrats and Republicans in President Obama’s final two years in office.
articles.lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — After years of clashes and a grudging truce, fiscal and economic policy was brought back to center stage by the wave of Republican electoral victories on Tuesday, with President Obama and the new congressional leadership expressing hope that they could reach deals to simplify the tax code, promote trade and eliminate the budget deficit.

articles.headline: Court Upholds Marriage Bans in Four States
articles.snippet: Setting up a Supreme Court case, the decision overturned lower court rulings in Kentucky, Michigan, Ohio and Tennessee that were in favor of same-sex marriage.
articles.abstract: Setting up a Supreme Court case, the decision overturned lower court rulings in Kentucky, Michigan, Ohio and Tennessee that were in favor of same-sex marriage.
articles.lead_paragraph: A federal appeals court in Ohio upheld on Thursday the right of four states to ban same-sex marriage, contradicting rulings by four similar courts and almost certainly sending the issue on a rapid trajectory to the Supreme Court.

articles.headline: Stars Offer Rewards and Risks to Charities
articles.snippet: A famous face can attract donations and recognition a nonprofit group, but public figures can also behave in ways that harm a cause.
articles.abstract: A famous face can attract donations and recognition a nonprofit group, but public figures can also behave in ways that harm a cause.
articles.lead_paragraph: Joe Torre, the Hall of Fame baseball player and manager, was standing on a trading floor in Midtown Manhattan, surrounded by people dressed as Minnie Mouse, Gilligan, a “Top Gun” pilot, Oompa Loompas (from “Charlie and the Chocolate Factory”), John Lennon (in his protest phase), assorted pirates and the Grim Reaper, who was in charge.

articles.headline: More Than 600 Reported Chemical Exposure in Iraq, Pentagon Acknowledges
articles.snippet: Defense officials said they failed to recognize the scope of the reports from Americans who served in Iraq, or to offer them adequate care.
articles.abstract: Defense officials said they failed to recognize the scope of the reports from Americans who served in Iraq, or to offer them adequate care.
articles.lead_paragraph: More than 600 American service members since 2003 have reported to military medical staff members that they believe they were exposed to chemical warfare agents in Iraq, but the Pentagon failed to recognize the scope of the reported cases or offer adequate tracking and treatment to those who may have been injured, defense officials say.

articles.headline: Doing Good in Harm’s Way
articles.snippet: Those who go abroad to scenes of disaster or conflict already take considerable personal risks — and those who go where Ebola is prevalent can face misunderstanding at home as well.
articles.abstract: Those who go abroad to scenes of disaster or conflict already take considerable personal risks — and those who go where Ebola is prevalent can face misunderstanding at home as well.
articles.lead_paragraph: As Dr. Rick Sacra prepared to fly to Liberia to treat patients in the Ebola zone, he prepared for the worst.

articles.headline: Takata Saw and Hid Risk in Airbags in 2004, Former Workers Say
articles.snippet: When secret tests a decade ago showed its airbags could crack and explode, the company tried to erase the evidence, former employees said.
articles.abstract: When secret tests a decade ago showed its airbags could crack and explode, the company tried to erase the evidence, former employees said.
articles.lead_paragraph: Alarmed by a report a decade ago that one of its airbags had ruptured and spewed metal debris at a driver in Alabama, the Japanese manufacturer Takata secretly conducted tests on 50 airbags it retrieved from scrapyards, according to two former employees involved in the tests, one of whom was a senior member of its testing lab.

articles.headline: In Ukraine Crisis, U.S. Businesses Face Tit-for-Tat Response to Sanctions
articles.snippet: American brands doing business in Russia have become political targets since the European Union and United States enacted sanctions.
articles.abstract: American brands doing business in Russia have become political targets since the European Union and United States enacted sanctions.
articles.lead_paragraph: MOSCOW — The scene was straight out of “C.S.I.,” food safety edition.

articles.headline: Doubting the Economic Data? Consider the Source
articles.snippet: If government economic statistics prove to be wrong, it may have more to do with how they are compiled than with deliberate manipulation.
articles.abstract: If government economic statistics prove to be wrong, it may have more to do with how they are compiled than with deliberate manipulation.
articles.lead_paragraph: The economic statistics are fake. There is no real economic recovery.

articles.headline: Midterms, for Clinton Team, Aren’t All Gloom
articles.snippet: The Democratic debacle in Tuesday’s midterm elections has put fresh urgency on Hillary Rodham Clinton’s efforts to create a blueprint for a 2016 presidential candidacy.
articles.abstract: The Democratic debacle in Tuesday’s midterm elections has put fresh urgency on Hillary Rodham Clinton’s efforts to create a blueprint for a 2016 presidential candidacy.
articles.lead_paragraph: In the coming weeks, Hillary Rodham Clinton will stop delivering paid speeches. She will embark on an unofficial listening tour to gather ideas from the business community, union leaders and others. And she will seek advice from such far-flung advisers as an ad man in Austin, Tex., behind the iconic “Don’t Mess With Texas” campaign and a leading strategist at a Boston-based public affairs consulting firm with ties to the Kennedys.

articles.headline: Jobs Data Show Steady Gains, but Stagnant Wages Temper Optimism
articles.snippet: While the report was upbeat, with a survey finding a big increase in the number of people who found a job last month, wage growth continued to drag.
articles.abstract: While the report was upbeat, with a survey finding a big increase in the number of people who found a job last month, wage growth continued to drag.
articles.lead_paragraph: Only days after many voters complained of worsening economic prospects, the new employment report from the government on Friday provided fresh evidence that the economy was actually getting better, with a sizable jump in the number of people saying they found a job last month.

articles.headline: Loretta Lynch, Federal Prosecutor, Will Be Nominated for Attorney General
articles.snippet: Ms. Lynch, the top federal prosecutor in Brooklyn, is the leading contender to succeed Eric H. Holder Jr., who is stepping down.
articles.abstract: Ms. Lynch, the top federal prosecutor in Brooklyn, is the leading contender to succeed Eric H. Holder Jr., who is stepping down.
articles.lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — President Obama will nominate Loretta E. Lynch, the top federal prosecutor in Brooklyn, to be the next attorney general, reaching outside his inner circle to fill a key post, the White House said Friday.
articles.byline: By Julie Hirschfeld Davis and Matt Apuzzo
